CreditLine: Promised gift of John and Berthe Ford
Description: The central figure in this busy and lively painting is Vajradhara, regarded as the Adibuddha or Primordial Buddha and the embodiment of "'sunyata" (emptiness or void). The concept appears for the first time in the text "Kalachakratantra" (which was probably composed in the 10th century), embodied as a monotheistic figure presiding over the five transcendental Buddhas. In both Nepal and Tibet he is a very important deity, and the well-known shrine of Svayambhunath in the Kathmandu Valley is dedicated to Vajradhara as Adibuddha. In reality he is self-born, self-existent, eternal, and without form, a concept that clearly reflects Vedantic theology.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Holy Madness: Portraits of Tantric Siddhas
Exhibitions.Textblock: Holy Madness: Portraits of Tantric Siddhas. Rubin Museum of Art, New York. 2006.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Desire and Devotion: Art from India, Nepal, and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection
Exhibitions.Textblock: Desire and Devotion: Art from India, Nepal, and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore; Santa Barbara Museum of Art, Santa Barbara; Albuquerque Museum, Albuquerque; Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham. 2001-2003.

Medium: pigments, gesso, and gold on cotton
Provenance: Chino Ronconi, Paris [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; John and Berthe Ford, Baltimore, November 1992, by purchase.
Title: Vajradhara with Mahasiddhas
